revisions.rev:
{{Infobox software | name = VLC media player | logo = [[File:VLC Icon.svg|64px]] | screenshot = [[File:Vlc 1.0.6 ubuntu lucid.png|250px]] | caption = VLC media player 1.0.6 running on [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]] and playing [[Sintel]]. | collapsible = | developer = [[VideoLAN]] Project | released = 1 February 2001 | frequently_updated = yes | programming language = [[C (programming language)|C]], [[C++]], [[Objective-C]] using [[Qt (toolkit)|Qt]] | operating system = [[GNU]], [[Linux]],
[[Windows 2000]] SP4 or later,
[[Mac OS X Leopard|Mac OS X 10.5]] or later,
[[FreeBSD]], [[Syllable Desktop (operating system)|Syllable]], [[OS/2]], [[BeOS]] [http://www.videolan.org/vlc/#download Official Downloads of VLC Media Player] | language = 53 languages | genre = [[media player (application software)|Media player]] | license = [[GNU General Public License]] v2 or later | website = [http://www.videolan.org/vlc videolan.org/vlc] }} '''VLC media player''' is a [[free software|free]] and [[open source]] [[media player (application software)|media player]] and [[multimedia framework]] written by the [[VideoLAN]] project. VLC is a [[porting|portable]] multimedia player, encoder, and streamer supporting many audio and video [[codec]]s and [[file format]]s as well as [[DVD]]s, [[video CD|VCDs]], and various [[streaming media|streaming]] [[communications protocol|protocols]]. It is able to stream over [[computer network|networks]] and to transcode multimedia files and save them into various formats. ''VLC'' used to stand for ''VideoLAN Client'', but since VLC is no longer simply a client, that [[initialism]] no longer applies.{{cite web | url=http://www.jbkempf.com/blog/post/2006/11/23/VLC-Name | title=VLC Name | author=Jean-Baptiste Kempf | date=November 23, 2006 | work=Yet another blog for JBKempf | accessdate=2007-02-24}}{{cite web | url=http://wiki.videolan.org/Intellectual_Properties#Names_.2F_Trademark | title=Intellectual Properties | author=VideoLAN Team | work=VideoLAN Wiki | accessdate=2007-07-30}} It is a [[cross-platform]] media player, with versions for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Mac OS X]], [[GNU]], [[Linux]], [[BeOS]], [[MorphOS]], [[Berkeley Software Distribution|BSD]], [[Solaris (operating system)|Solaris]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[iOS (Apple)|iOS]], and [[eComStation]].{{cite web | url =http://www.videolan.org/vlc/features.php | title =VLC playback Features | publisher =VideoLAN | accessdate =2010-05-11 }} The default distribution of VLC includes a large number of [[free software|free]] decoding and encoding libraries, avoiding the need for finding/calibrating proprietary plugins. Many of VLC's [[codec]]s are provided by the [[libavcodec]] library from the [[FFmpeg]] project, but it uses mainly its own [[muxer]] and demuxers. It also gained distinction as the first player to support playback of encrypted DVDs on Linux by using the [[libdvdcss]] DVD decryption library. ==History== The VideoLan project was originally started as an academic project in 1996. It was intended to consist of a client and server to stream videos across a campus network. VLC was the client for the VideoLAN project, with VLC standing for ''VideoLan Client''. Originally developed by students at the [[Ãcole Centrale Paris]], it is now developed by contributors worldwide and is coordinated by the [[VideoLAN]] non-profit organization. Rewritten from scratch in 1998, it was released under the GPL on 1 February 2001. The functionality of the server program, ''VideoLan Server'' (VLS), has mostly been subsumed into VLC and has been deprecated.{{cite web | url=http://www.videolan.org/vlc/streaming.html | title=VideoLAN - The streaming solution | accessdate=2009-03-08 }} The project name has been changed to ''VLC'' because there is no longer a client/server infrastructure. The cone icon used in VLC is a reference to the [[traffic cone]]s collected by Ecole Centrale's Networking Students' Association.{{cite web | url=http://www.nanocrew.net/2005/06/23/vlc-cone/ | title=VLC cone | author=[[Jon Lech Johansen]] | date=June 23, 2005 | work=So sue me: Jon Lech Johansenâs blog | accessdate=2007-02-24 }} The cone icon design was changed from a hand drawn low resolution icon{{cite web | url=http://git.videolan.org/?p=vlc.git;a=blob_plain;f=share/vlc48x48.png;hb=85e4b3a17d6a107a0f73be40c52c080354b3ddd0 | title=vlc48x48.png | format=PNG | work=VideoLAN Project | accessdate=2010-03-15 }} to a higher resolution [[computer-generated imagery|CGI]]-rendered version in 2006, illustrated by Richard Ãiestad.{{cite web | url=http://git.videolan.org/?p=vlc.git;a=blob_plain;f=share/vlc48x48.png;hb=9ef388cc16e200fa0a4571f9b006c0d58e9ba115 | title=vlc48x48.png | format=PNG | work=VideoLAN Project | accessdate=2010-03-15 }} After 13 years of development, version 1.0.0 of VLC media player was released on July 7, 2009.{{cite web | url=http://arstechnica.com/open-source/news/2009/07/vlc-10-officially-released.ars | title=VLC 1.0 officially released after more than 10 years of work| accessdate=2009-07-07 }} VLC is 3rd in the sourceforge.net overall download count.[http://sourceforge.net/top/topalltime.php?type=downloads] SourceForge.net. VLC was available for the [[iPad]], [[iPhone]], and [[iPod Touch]] from the [[App Store (iOS)|Apple AppStore]], but was pulled due to a licensing conflict between the GPL and the iTunes Store agreement.{{cite web|title=Apple pulls VLC media player from the App Store|url=http://www.macnn.com/articles/11/01/07/move.said.to.be.related.to.licensing.dispute/|publisher=MacNN|accessdate=3 June 2011|date=2011-01-07}} ==Design principles== VLC 1.0.0 has more than 380 modules.{{cite web | url=http://trac.videolan.org/vlc/browser/modules/LIST | title=VLC media player List of modules | work=VLC media player trac system }} VLC, like most [[multimedia framework]]s, has a very [[modular (programming)|modular]] design which makes it easier to include modules/plugins for new file formats, codecs, or streaming methods. The VLC core creates dynamically its own graph of modules depending on the situation: input protocol, input file format, input codec, video card capabilities and other parameters. In VLC, almost everything is a module, like interfaces, video and audio outputs, controls, scalers, codecs, and audio/[[filter (video)|video filters]]. ===Interfaces=== [[File:Vlc wx kde.png|thumb|right|VLC with the [[wxWidgets]] interface, running on [[KDE]]]] In VLC, interfaces are modules, which means that VLC's core can launch one, many, or no interfaces. The default [[GUI]] is based on [[Qt (toolkit)|Qt]] 4 for Windows and Linux, [[Cocoa (API)|Cocoa]] for Mac OS X, and [[Be API]] on BeOS; but all give a similar standard interface. The old default [[GUI]] was based on [[wxWidgets|wx]] on Windows and Linux.{{cite web | url=http://www.jbkempf.com/blog/post/2007/02/10/Qt4-Interface | title=Qt4 Interface | author=Jean-Baptiste Kempf | date=February 10, 2007 | work=Yet another blog for JBKempf | accessdate=2007-03-07 }} [[File:Vlc115macosx.png|thumb|right|VLC v1.1.5 on [[Mac OS X Leopard]] ]] The interface contains an [[Easter egg (media)|easter egg]] which changes the VLC traffic cone logo so that it's wearing a [[Santa hat]]. The logo changes on December 18, one week before [[Christmas]], and reverts to its normal appearance on January 1. VLC supports highly customizable [[Skin (computing)|skins]] through the skins2 interface, also supporting [[Winamp]] 2 and [[XMMS]] skins. The customizable skins feature can malfunction depending on which version is being used.[[File:Skin VLC eDark.png|thumb|VLC with the popular eDark theme]] [[File:VLCncurses.png|thumb|right|VLC with the [[ncurses]] interface, running on [[Mac OS X]]]] For [[computer console|console]] users, VLC has a remote control interface and an [[ncurses]] interface. As VLC can act as a streaming server, rather than a media player, it can be useful to control it from a remote location and there are interfaces allowing this. The Remote Control Interface is a text-based interface for doing this. There are also interfaces using [[telnet]] and [[HTTP]] ([[Ajax (programming)|Ajax]]). ===Control=== In addition to these interfaces, it is possible to control VLC in different ways: * Configurable hotkeys * [[Mouse gesture]]s * [[LIRC]] and infrared controllers * [[D-Bus]] * Laptop motion * [[application software|Apps]] for operating systems, such as [[Android (operating system)|Android]] and [[iOS (Apple)|iOS]] (iPad, iPhone, iPod Touch) ==Features== [[File:VLCmenu 1 0 6.png|thumb|right|VLC's right-click Menu on GNU/Linux (Kubuntu 10.04)]] Because VLC is a [[Packet (information technology)|packet-based]] media player, it can play the video content of some damaged, incomplete, or unfinished videos. (For example, files still downloading via [[peer-to-peer]] (P2P) networks). It also plays m2t [[MPEG transport stream]]s (.TS) files while they are still being digitized from an [[HDV]] camera via a [[FireWire]] cable, making it possible to monitor the video as it is being played. The player can also use libcdio to access [[.iso]] files so that users can play files on a [[disk image]], even if the user's operating system cannot work directly with .iso images. VLC supports all audio and video formats and all file formats supported by [[libavcodec]] and libavformat. This means that VLC can play back [[H.264/MPEG-4 AVC|H.264]] or [[MPEG-4]] video as well as support [[Flash Video|FLV]] or [[Material Exchange Format|MXF]] file formats "out of the box" using FFmpeg's libraries. Alternatively, VLC has modules for codecs that are not based on FFmpeg's libraries. VLC is one of the [[free software]] and [[open source]] DVD players that ignores [[DVD region code#Software DVD players|DVD region coding]] on RPC-1 firmware drives, making it a region-free player. However, it does not do the same on RPC-2 firmware drives. VLC media player has some filters that can distort, rotate, split, [[deinterlace]], mirror videos, create display walls, or add a logo overlay. It can also output video as [[ASCII art]]. VLC media player can play [[High-definition video|high definition]] recordings of [[D-VHS]] tapes duplicated to a computer using CapDVHS.exe. This offers another way to archive all D-VHS tapes with the DRM copy freely tag. Using a [[FireWire]] connection from cable boxes to computers, VLC can stream live, unencrypted content to a monitor or HDTV. VLC media player can display the playing video as the [[computer wallpaper|desktop wallpaper]], like [[Windows DreamScene]], by using [[DirectX]], only available on Windows operating systems. VLC media player can create [[screencast]]s and record the desktop. On Microsoft Windows, VLC also supports the Direct Media Object (DMO) framework and can thus make use of some third-party [[dynamic-link library|DLLs]]. On most platforms, VLC can tune in to and view DVB-C, DVB-T, and DVB-S channels. On Mac OS X the separate EyeTV plugin is required, on Windows it requires the card's BDA Drivers. VLC can be installed or run directly from a [[USB flash drive]] or other external drive. VLC can be extended through scripting. It uses the [[Lua (programming language)|Lua]] scripting language.[http://addons.videolan.org/ Addons for VLC]. Retrieved on 2011-22-5. VLC can play videos in the [[AVCHD]] format, a highly compressed format used in recent [[High-definition video|HD]] camcorders. VLC can generate a number of [[music visualization]] displays. ==Use of VLC with other programs== ===API=== {{Infobox software | name = libVLC | logo = | developer = [[VideoLAN]] Project | released = 1 February 2001 | latest release version = | latest release date = | latest preview version = | latest preview date = | frequently updated = | programming language = [[C (programming language)|C]] | operating system = [[Cross-platform]] | platform = Native, [[.NET Framework|.NET]], [[Java (programming language)|Java]], [[Python (programming language)|Python]], [[Go (programming language)|Go]], [[Cocoa (API)|Cocoa]]{{cite web|url=http://wiki.videolan.org/Libvlc |title=libVLC - VideoLAN Wiki |publisher=Wiki.videolan.org |date=2010-09-09 |accessdate=2010-10-06}} | size = | language = Multilingual | status = | genre = Multimedia [[library (computing)|Library]] | license = [[GNU General Public License]] | website = {{URL|http://wiki.videolan.org/Libvlc}} {{en icon}} }} Several [[API]]s can connect to VLC and use its functionality: * libVLC API â the VLC Core, for [[C (programming language)|C]], [[C++]], and [[C Sharp (programming language)|C#]] * VLCKit â an Objective-C framework for Mac OS X * [[JavaScript]] API â the evolution of ActiveX API and Firefox integration * [[D-Bus]] controls * [[Go (programming language)|Go]] binding{{cite web|url=http://github.com/jteeuwen/go-pkg-libvlc |title=Go binding Project |publisher=Github.com |date=2010-08-25 |accessdate=2010-10-06}} * [[C Sharp (programming language)|C#]] interface * [[Python (programming language)|Python]] controls{{cite web|url=http://wiki.videolan.org/Python_bindings |title=Python bindings - VideoLAN Wiki |publisher=Wiki.videolan.org |date=2010-09-30 |accessdate=2010-10-06}} * [[Java (programming language)|Java]] API{{cite web|url=http://wiki.videolan.org/Java_bindings |title=Java binding Project |publisher=Wiki.videolan.org |date=2010-01-25 |accessdate=2010-10-06}} * [[DirectShow]] filters{{cite web | last=Anderson | first=Dean | coauthors= Lamberson, Jim | title=Using VideoLan VLC in DirectShow | work=An open source bridge from VLC to DirectShow | year=2007 | url=http://www.sensoray.com/support/videoLan.htm | accessdate=2008-02-15}} * [[Object Pascal|Delphi/Pascal]] API: PasLibVlc by: "Robert JÄdrzejczyk"[http://www.prog.olsztyn.pl/paslibvlc Prog.olsztyn.pl libvlc for Delphi and FreePascal]. Retrieved on 2011-05-22. ===Browser plugins=== On Windows, Linux, Mac, and some other Unix-like platforms, VLC provides an [[NPAPI]] plugin,{{cite web|url=http://www.videolan.org/doc/play-howto/en/ch04.html#id293992 |title=Chapter 4. Advanced use of VLC |publisher=Videolan.org |date= |accessdate=2010-10-06}} which enables users to view [[QuickTime]], [[Windows Media]], [[MP3]], and [[Ogg]] files embedded in websites without using additional products. It supports many [[web browser]]s including [[Mozilla Firefox|Firefox]], [[Mozilla Application Suite]], and other [[Netscape]] plug-in based browsers; [[Safari (web browser)|Safari]], [[Google Chrome|Chrome]], and other [[WebKit]] based browsers; and [[Opera (web browser)|Opera]]. [[Google]] used this plugin to build the [[Google Video]] web browser plugin before switching to use [[Adobe Flash]].{{cite web|url=http://code.google.com/patches.html |title=Open Source Patches and Mirrored Packages - Google Code |publisher=Code.google.com |date= |accessdate=2010-10-06}} Starting with version 0.8.2, VLC also provides an [[Component Object Model|ActiveX]] plugin, which lets people view QuickTime (MOV), Windows Media, MP3, and Ogg files embedded in websites when using [[Internet Explorer]]. ===Applications which use the VLC plugin=== VLC can handle incomplete files and can be used to preview files being downloaded. Several programs make use of this, including eMule and [[KCeasy]]. The free/open-source Internet television application [[Miro (software)|Miro]] also uses VLC code. [[HandBrake]], an open-source video encoder, loads [[libdvdcss]] from VLC Media Player. ==Format support== ===Readable formats=== [[File:Vlc mediaplayer 0.9.8a runing on KDE 4.2.1 with fedora 10.png|thumb|right|250px|VLC running under [[KDE]]]] VLC can read several formats, depending on the [[operating system]] VLC is running on.{{cite web | url=http://www.videolan.org/vlc/features.html | title=VLC features list | work=VideoLAN Project | accessdate=2007-02-24 }} ; '''Input''' : [[User Datagram Protocol|UDP]]/[[Real-time Transport Protocol|RTP]] [[unicast]] or [[multicast]], HTTP, [[FTP]], [[Microsoft Media Services|MMS]], [[Real Time Streaming Protocol|RTSP]], [[Real Time Messaging Protocol|RTMP]], DVDs, VCD, [[SVCD]], [[CD Audio]], [[Digital Video Broadcasting|DVB]], Video acquisition (via V4l and DirectShow), [[RSS (file format)|RSS]]/[[Atom (standard)|Atom]] Feeds, and from files stored on the user's computer. ; '''[[Container format (digital)|Container formats]]''': [[3GP]],To use AMR as audio codec, VLC and FFmpeg must be compiled with AMR support. This is because the AMR license is not compatible with the VLC license. [[Advanced Systems Format|ASF]], [[Audio Video Interleave|AVI]], [[FLV]], [[Matroska]], [[Musical Instrument Digital Interface]] (.mid/.midi),This feature needs sound fonts and might not work on every OS [[QuickTime Video|QuickTime]], [[MP4]], [[Ogg]], [[OGM]], [[WAV]], [[MPEG-2]] ([[Elementary stream|ES]], [[MPEG program stream|PS]], [[MPEG transport stream|TS]], PVA, [[MP3]]), [[AIFF]], Raw audio, Raw DV, [[MXF]], [[VOB]]. ; '''[[Template:Compression Formats|Video formats]]''': [[Cinepak]], [[Dirac (codec)|Dirac]], [[DV]], [[H.263]], [[H.264/MPEG-4 AVC]] (8-bit; nightly builds also have [[Hi10P|10-bit H.264]] support), [[HuffYUV]], [[Indeo]] 3,Indeo 4 and 5 codecs are not supported [[MJPEG]], [[MPEG-1]], MPEG-2, [[MPEG-4 Part 2]], [[RealVideo]] 3&4,from 0.9.9 and over [[Sorenson codec|Sorenson]] (thus enabling direct playback of the modified Sorenson [[H.263]] encoded videos downloaded from [[YouTube]]), [[Theora]], [[VC-1]],This is from the 0.8.6 version. [[VP5]], [[VP6]], [[VP8]], and some [[WMV]]. ; '''Subtitles''': DVD, SVCD, DVB, OGM, [[SubStation Alpha]], [[SubRip]], [[Advanced SubStation Alpha]], [[MPEG-4 Timed Text]], [[Text file]], [[Vobsub]], MPL2,This is present in 0.9.0 and newer version. [[Teletext]]. ; '''Audio formats''':{{cite web |url=http://www.videolan.org/vlc/features.php?cat=audio |title=VLC playback Features |author=VideoLAN team |accessdate=2010-01-03}} [[Advanced Audio Coding|AAC]], [[AC3]], [[Apple Lossless|ALAC]], [[Adaptive Multi-Rate|AMR]], [[Digital Theater System|DTS]], DV Audio, [[XM (file format)|XM]], [[Free Lossless Audio Codec|FLAC]], [[MACE (codec)|MACE]], [[MOD (file format)|Mod]], [[MP3]], [[PLS (file format)|PLS]], QDM2/QDMC, [[RealAudio]],Real Audio playback is provided through the FFmpeg library which only supports the Cook (RealAudio G2 / RealAudio 8) decoder at the moment. [[Speex]], [[S3M|Screamtracker 3/S3M]], [[TTA (codec)|TTA]], [[Vorbis]], [[WavPack]],{{As of|2010}}, only supported in mono and stereo, so no multichannel support. [[Windows Media Audio|WMA]] (WMA 1/2, WMA 3 partially). ===Output formats for streaming/encoding=== VLC can [[transcode]] into several formats depending on the operating system. ; '''Container formats''': ASF, AVI, FLV, Fraps, MP4, Ogg, Wav, MPEG-2 (ES, PS, TS, PVA, MP3), MPJPEG, FLAC, QuickTime, Matroska ; '''Video formats''': H.263, H.264/MPEG-4 AVC, MJPEG, MPEG-1, MPEG-2, MPEG-4 Part 2, VP5, VP6, VP8, Theora, DV ; '''Audio formats''': AAC, AC3, DV Audio, FLAC, MP3,VLC must be compiled with mp3lame support Speex, Vorbis ; '''Streaming protocols''': [[User Datagram Protocol|UDP]], [[Hypertext Transfer Protocol|HTTP]], [[Real-time Transport Protocol|RTP]], [[Real Time Streaming Protocol|RTSP]], [[Microsoft Media Services|MMS]], file ==Legality== The VLC media player software installers for the Mac OS X platform and the Windows platform include the [[libdvdcss|libdvdcss DVD decryption library]], even though this library may be legally restricted in certain jurisdictions.{{cite web |url=http://www.videolan.org/support/faq.html |title=VideoLAN - VideoLAN - Frequently Asked Questions |accessdate=2010-11-12 |publisher=[[VideoLAN]]}} ===USA=== At least one recent release of the VLC media player software is able to read video and audio data from DVDs that incorporate [[Content Scramble System]] (CSS) encryption, even though the VLC media player software lacks a CSS decryption license.{{cite web |url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/168622/ |title=VLC Video Player's New DVD-Copying Feature Could Run Afoul of the MPAA - PCWorld |date=2009-07-17 |accessdate=2010-11-12 |publisher=[[PC World (magazine)|PCWorld]] |author=Horton, Steve}} The unauthorized decryption of CSS-encrypted DVD content and/or the unauthorized distribution of CSS decryption tools may violate the US [[Digital Millennium Copyright Act]], although the decryption of CSS-encrypted DVD content has been temporarily authorized for certain purposes (such as [[documentary film]]making that uses short portions of DVD content for criticism and/or commentary) under the Digital Millennium Copyright Act [[Digital Millennium Copyright Act#Anti-circumvention exemptions|anticircumvention exemptions]] that were issued by the [[US Copyright Office]] in 2010.{{cite web |url=http://www.copyright.gov/1201/ |title=Rulemaking on Exemptions from Prohibition on Circumvention of Technological Measures that Control Access to Copyrighted Works |date=2010-07-28 |accessdate=2010-11-14 |publisher=[[US Copyright Office]]}} (These exemptions do not change the DMCA's ban on the distribution of CSS decryption tools.){{cite web |url=http://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2005/11/dmca-triennial-rulemaking-failing-consumers-completely |title=DMCA Triennial Rulemaking: Failing Consumers Completely |year=2005 |accessdate=2010-11-14 |publisher=[[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] |author=von Lohmann, Fred |authorlink=Fred von Lohmann}} ==See also== {{Portal|Free software}} * [[Comparison of video player software]] * [[List of codecs|List of multimedia (audio/video) codecs]] ==Notes and references== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{commons|VLC}} *{{Official
